newsitem.title: INDIA: India monetary policy seen helping bank profits.
newsitem.headline: India monetary policy seen helping bank profits.

text.p: India's central bank initiatives on the weekend to boost liquidity and cut lending rates will have a positive impact on bank profits if they spur credit growth, analysts said on Tuesday.

"The reduction in cash reserve ratio (CRR) by two percentage points and the decrease in term deposit rate by one percentage point will positively impact banking sector profitability," ICICI Securities and Finance (I-Sec) said in a report.

It said the cut in CRR and a reduction in maximum interest payable on deposits up to one year, to 10 percent a year from 11 percent, announced by the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) on Saturday, should theoretically result in a proportionate increase in profits.
But some analysts said while the overall impact of the monetary policy for the second half of 1996/97 (April-March) would be positive, it might not translate to immediate profits.

"The advantage of the CRR cut, to a large extent, will be nullified by the deposit rate cut," said S.R. Krishnan, analyst at Peregrine Capital India. He did not expect more than a marginal increase in bank profits for the current year.

The RBI said the decision to cut the CRR and deposit rate were aimed at prompting a cut in the lending rate. The state-run Bank of Baroda, immediately announced a cut in its prime lending rate by 50 basis points to 15.0 percent.

"Every cut in CRR gives additional earnings," RBI governor Chakravarty Rangarajan told a news conference on Saturday. The CRR cut, in four stages, would release over 85 billion rupees ($2.4 billion) of funds locked up with the central bank, analysts said.
"State Bank of India profits should rise," said a vice-president of a private bank. "But for most other banks, profits should be around the same level as last year."

"For State Bank of India, two percentage points (cut in the CRR) means lots of money which they can invest anywhere," he said. He said most other state-run banks would find the cost of retaining funds high.
The changes would impact on profits only in 1997/98, a bank treasurer said. "The deposit rates won't come down fast as the reduced rate applies only to new deposits," he said.
But he said bank profits should grow next year provided credit picks up. But there was no sign of this yet, he said.
Banks have complained of a fall in credit this year.
"Banks will record about seven to eight percent growth in earnings per share for 1996/97," I-Sec said.

"However, the benefit of the reduction in cost will be felt for the entire 12 months during 1997/98, compared to only six months in 1996/97. Banks will correspondingly record stronger earnings growth in 1997/98," it said.
Amit Rajpal, analyst at Prime Broking, said he expected banks to record a fall in interest income this year. "I don't see much allocation going into credit," he said.
"This policy will be more or less profit-neutral," he said.
